sect1.title: Overview
sect1.para: Provides functionalities to create steppers for implicit methods. Recall that implicit methods update the state of a system by solving a system of equations involving both the current and next state. An implicit stepper is an object that knows how to do one such implicit step.
Pressio implicit steppers are applicable to any system written in continuous-time form: \[ \frac{d \boldsymbol{y}}{dt} = \boldsymbol{f}(\boldsymbol{y},t; ...) \]
and/or in a discrete-time form \[ \boldsymbol{R}(\boldsymbol{y}, \boldsymbol{y_{n-1}}, ..., t_n, dt_n; ...) = \boldsymbol{0} \]
Here, $y$ is the state, $f$ the velocity, $t$ is time, and $R$ is the residual.

sect1.title: API for continuous-time systems
sect1.para: In this case, pressio exposes the following functions to create an instance of a desired stepper:

sect2.title: Parameters

listitem.para: StateType: data type of the state
SystemType: class defining how to create an instance of the velocity $f$ and how to compute it;
ResidualPolicyType, JacobianPolicyType: policy types if you want to use custom ones to compute the discrete operators.

sect2.para:
Notes:
if you use the first overload above, pressio uses default policies to compute the residual and jacobian.
the second overload allows you to define custom policies to compute the discrete operators

listitem.para: StateType: must be copy constructible and the following condition must be true: std::is_same<StateType, typename SystemType::state_type>::value == true
the nested type aliases must be valid types since they are detected by pressio

sect2.title: If you use custom policies:
sect2.para: If you want to use custom policies for computing residual and Jacobian, you need are responsible for ensuring things are correct. In particular, you should be aware of the following:

listitem.para: State: argument passed to compute method contains the prediction at n+1.

auxStates, auxRhs (whose type you don't need to know) contain the needed auxiliary states and RHS evaluations, respectively, needed to compute the operators for a certain scheme. All you need to know about these containers is the following:

sect2.title: What to do after a stepper is created?
sect2.para: Any stepper created using the functions above is guaranteed to satisfy the "steppable" concept discussed here. Therefore, once you create a stepper, you can use the advancers to step forward or you can use your own. An example is below:

sect2.title: Required specializations for custom types
sect2.para: When using custom data types not supported in pressio ops, you need to provide specializations of a trait class and certain operations and make them "visible" to the compiler to find them and such that pressio can operate on your data. For the sake of explanation, suppose that you use double as value type and ACustomStateType is what you use for the state, ACustomMatrixType is what you use for matrix, then you would need to do something like this:
Obviously, if you want to use pressio nonlinear solvers, then you need provide also the specializations described here.

listitem.para:
StateType:
type of the data structure you use for the state

SystemType:
class defining how to create and compute the residual and Jacobian
